   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with ulcerative colitis, GI bleeding, severe right
   ventricular dysfunction, gross volume overload, s/p PFO repair with
   endovascular device, presenting from PACU after successful C-Scope and
   EGD, in stable condition.
   .
   # ULCERATIVE COLITIS / GI BLEEDING: Given known UC and recent dual
   antiplatelet therapy, suspect exacerbation of underlying inflammatory
   process. Given UGI ulcer however would consider Crohn's disease in
   differential diagnosis. Pt is s/p local therapy for both LGI ulcers and
   UGI ulcer.
   -- monitor hct q8H
   -- continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **]
   -- f/u GI recs
   -- hold beta blocker until hct has stablized
   -- Hold off on diuresis.
   .
   # R CHF: 2/2 L sided diastolic dysfunction.  Patient with elevated on
   Patient was significantly volume overloaded but diuresis was limited by
   R to L shunt through PFO. She underwent PFO closure on [**3-14**]. After
   closure attempts to diuresis has been unsuccessful. Patient had
   previously been on Lasix gtt and metolazone 5 mg [**Hospital1 **] with poor UOP and
   increasing creatinine and previously required midodrine to maintain
   increased SVR to allow diuresis.  Renal was consulted on [**2108-3-18**] for
   possible ultrafitration/HD to remove excess fluid.  For now, will hold
   on diuresis as there is concern for patient becoming hemodynamically
   unstable from further bleeding.
   - midodrine 10mg PO TID (0800, 1200, and 1600 hrs)
   .
   #ARF, stage III chronic renal failure:  Cr 2.5, b/l 1.5-1.8.  Likely
   secondary to use of diuretics in patient.  Patient a possible candidate
   for HD filtration.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - renal aware of patient
   .
   # s/p PFO closure: s/p percutaneous closure [**2108-3-14**] without
   complication.  Echo [**3-15**] shows mild residual shunt 18 gauge had to be
   used
   - echo shows no evidence of displacement of PFO closure device
   - repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - continue aspirin and plavix
   .
   Afib: chronic
   - no anticoagulation; continue aspirin
   - currently rate controlled
   - holding beta blocker until hct stabilizes
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with p-boots
   -Bowel regimen
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .

   .

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis, GI bleeding, severe right ventricular dysfunction, and gross volume overload. She underwent percutaneous closure of a patent foramen ovale (PFO) repair with an endovascular device. The patient presented from the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) after successful C-Scope and esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD), in stable condition.

24-hour events:
The patient has allergies to lisinopril, which caused a rash and abdominal pain, as well as hives from cefazolin sodium and sulfa antibiotics. The last dose of antibiotics was given intravenously. The patient is currently receiving various infusions and other medications.

Review of systems:
The patient's review of systems remains unchanged from admission except for the following:

Vital signs:
The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.5°C (97.7°F), heart rate (HR) of 75 bpm with a range of 64-77 bpm, blood pressure (BP) ranging from 99/69 mmHg to 154/97 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) of 11 breaths per minute with a range of 7-19 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 97% on nasal cannula, and atrial fibrillation (AF) as the heart rhythm.

Physical examination:

   62 year old woman with ulcerative colitis, GI bleeding, severe right
   ventricular dysfunction, gross volume overload, s/p PFO repair with

   with persistent melena.
   .

   HCT has dropped from 26
 23 and is having melena.  Patient on dual
   antiplatelet agents for the PFO closure device.  Patient will need to
   stay in the ICU for further monitoring as patient may need intervention
   from GI.  At this point, patient
s transfusion goal should be > 30
   given her other underlying medical issues.
   -- Tranfuse 2u PRBCs for goal HCT > 30, with Lasix 100mg IV once
   -- monitor hct q8H
   -- continue ppi [**Hospital1 **]
   -- f/u GI recs
   -- hold beta blocker until hct has stablized
   .

   diastolic dysfunction.  Patient with small persistent PFO, despite
   closure.  Patient had been on Lasix gtt and metolazone 5 mg [**Hospital1 **] with
   poor UOP and increasing creatinine and previously required midodrine to
   maintain increased SVR to allow diuresis.  Renal was consulted on
   [**2108-3-18**] for possible ultrafitration/HD to remove excess fluid.  For
   now, will administer lasix boluses with transfusion.
   - Lasix 100mg IV once
   - Continue midodrine 10mg PO TID (0800, 1200, and 1600 hrs)
   .
   # Hypothermia:  During rounds, patient
s Temp was 95 PR.  Unclear
   etiology.  Patient
s TSH was elevated in past, FT4 was normal one month
   ago.
   - Warming blanket
   - Monitor.
   .
   #ARF, stage III chronic renal failure:  Cr 2.5, b/l 1.5-1.8.  Likely
   secondary to use of diuretics in patient.  Patient a possible candidate
   for HD filtration.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - Check urine lytes
   - appreciate renal recs
   .

   complication.  Echo [**3-15**] shows mild residual shunt as 18 gauge had to
   be used
   - repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - continue aspirin and plavix for one month, for now.
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis, GI bleeding, severe right ventricular dysfunction, gross volume overload, and previous percutaneous closure of patent foramen ovale (PFO). The patient is currently in the ICU after undergoing a C-Scope and EGD procedure.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 99/69 mmHg to 154/97 mmHg, respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient has atrial fibrillation, with an irregularly irregular rhythm.

Physical examination findings include a 10cm jugular venous distention (JVD), right parasternal lift with nondisplaced point of maximal impulse (PMI), mild bibasilar crackles in the lungs, 2+ lower extremity peripheral edema, and poor capillary refill. Neurological examination reveals preserved sensation and strength throughout.

Laboratory results show hemoglobin (Hb) of 7.5 g/dL, hematocrit (Hct) of 23.5%, leukocyte count (WBC) within normal range, platelet count (Plt) of 266 K/uL, creatinine (Cr) of 2.5 mg/dL, blood glucose (Glucose) of 105 mg/dL

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is critically ill and has several medical complications. The key points from the note are as follows:

1. The patient has a gastrointestinal (GI) bleed, which is being treated with blood transfusions and medications to reduce stomach acid production.

2. The patient has severe biventricular heart failure and a recent correction of a Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO).

3. The patient is experiencing respiratory distress but is currently stable on supplemental oxygen.

4. The patient has multiple sources of bleeding in the GI tract, including peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and superficial ulcerations in the sigmoid colon, likely related to ulcerative colitis.

5. The patient underwent patent foramen ovale closure surgery and is being advised to continue taking ASA and Plavix due to the presence of a PFO that was previously occluded.

6. The patient is anemic due to blood loss and requires further transfusions to maintain a hematocrit (Hct) level of 30.

7. The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation (A-Fib) that is rate-controlled.

8. The patient has acute-on-chronic renal failure and is being evaluated for ultrafiltration.

9. The patient is experiencing hypothermia and is being considered for re-evaluation of thyroid function tests (TFT) and adrenal axis.

10. The patient is currently NPO (nothing by mouth) pending completion of an evaluation.

Potential medical complications

The patient is extubated and remains on ASA and Plavix. They continue to experience melena (black, tarry stools), indicating ongoing GI bleeding.

2. Hypothermia: The patient's core temperature is slightly low at 36.5°C (97.7°F), which could be due to the stress of critical illness or inadequate warming in the ICU.

4. Respiratory distress: Although the patient

Summary of the Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis, severe right ventricular dysfunction, and previous percutaneous closure of a patent foramen ovale (PFO). She presented to the ICU after undergoing a colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) due to persistent melena. The patient has been experiencing poor urine output despite receiving blood transfusions and diuretics, and her hemoglobin concentration has dropped significantly. She is also hypothermic and has chronic atrial fibrillation.

Medical Complications:
1. Ulcerative Colitis/GI Bleeding: The patient has persistent melena despite previous interventions for gastrointestinal bleeding. She requires further monitoring and may need additional interventions from the gastroenterology department.
2. Right Heart Failure (CHF): The patient has severe right ventricular dysfunction leading to biventricular diastolic dysfunction. This condition is causing fluid overload and requires management with diuretics and other cardiac supportive measures.
3. Hypothermia: The patient's temperature is low, and the cause is unclear. It may be related to her underlying medical conditions or other factors.
4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate renal dysfunction, which could be secondary to the use of diuretics. She may require hemodialysis for filtration.
5. Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) Closure: The patient

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications. They presented with a gastrointestinal (GI) bleed and severe biventricular failure, which was recently corrected due to a patent foramen ovale (PFO) repair. The patient also has respiratory distress, anemia secondary to blood loss, congestive heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (A-Fib), acute on chronic renal failure, hypothermia, and requires nutritional support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. GI Bleed: The patient has multiple sources of GI bleeding, including peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and superficial ulcerations in the sigmoid colon. This can lead to further blood loss and potential shock.
2. Severe Biventricular Failure: The patient's heart is failing to pump blood effectively, leading to reduced cardiac output. This can result in organ dysfunction and poor perfusion.
3. Respiratory Distress: The patient is experiencing difficulty breathing, requiring supplemental oxygen. Prolonged respiratory distress can lead to respiratory failure.
4. Anemia: Due to blood loss, the patient has developed anemia. Severe anemia can cause fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. CHF: The patient's heart failure is affecting both ventricles, resulting in fluid accumulation and organ congestion. This can lead to worsening cardiac function and systemic complications.
6. A-Fib: The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation

- The patient presents with gastrointestinal bleeding in the setting of severe biventricular failure and recent correction of a patent foramen ovale (PFO).
- The patient is currently stable with respiratory distress, and oxygen is being maintained to keep SaO2 >90%. Respiratory status is being monitored.
- The GI bleed has multiple sources, including lower and upper GI tract, peptic ulcer disease (PUD), and superficial ulcerations in the sigmoid colon, likely related to ulcerative colitis.
- The patient has received a total of 4 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC) over the past week. IV access is maintained.
- Patent foramen ovale closure repair has been performed, and a smaller dose of aspirin (ASA) and holding Plavix per Cardiology is advised.
- Anemia is secondary to blood loss, and serial hematocrit (Hct) is being followed, with plans to transfuse to Hct >27.
- The patient has biventricular congestive heart failure (CHF), requiring careful fluid balance and following of vital signs. Aggressive diuresis may be required, and Cardiology is following up.
- The patient has atrial fibrillation (A-Fib) that is rate-controlled.
- Acute-on-chronic renal failure is present, pre-renal, perhaps in a low flow state. Renal Consultant is following up, and ultrafiltration is unable to di

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers,
   hct stable at 24 for over 24hrs, with baseline hct mid-upper 20s. Had
   multiple episodes of clots from rectum (Q15mins) overnight. Called GI
   and did NGL which was negative making UGIB less likely.  Transfused one
   unit pRBCs. Awaiting follow up Hct.
   - Hct Q2H
   - GI to consult formally today. [**Month (only) 60**] need to rescope
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: Still resistant to diureisis.
   Suspect not diuresing due to poor forward flow from right heart failure
   (left heart seeing low filling volumes). With gross fluid overload
   dilated right ventricle is likely worsening diastolic dysfunction and
   removing the excess fluid is likely the only way the patient will
   improve clinically. As she did not improve over day today with lasix
   gtt at 30/hr she has been transferred to CCU for ultrafiltration to
   help with fluid removal.
   - On UF with net negative 500mL. Goal is net negative 4L today.
   - Will need A-line for better BP measurements as cuff not [**Location (un) 308**] well
   - Renal will continue to follow and leave recs for CVVH
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction
   - Will continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Will continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence
   this does improve diastolic CHF.
   # Diarrhea: Likely from blood in GI tract still. Also consider C diff
   given prolonged hospitalization. No fevers, no evidence of infectious
   colitis on scope.
   - C Diff pending
   - Loperamide PRN if C diff negative
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr continued to trend up over
   the course of today. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely secondary to
   poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not suggestive
   of ATN. Concern that she will develop ischemic ATN if renal perfusion
   does not improve.
   - Appreciate renal recs
   - UF as above
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient has chronic persistent AF.
   - Control rate with beta blocker to allow as much diastolic filling of
   hypertrophied LV as possible.
   - Continue ASA for ppx->no coumadin given GIB recently
   # s/p PFO closure: s/p percutaneous closure [**2108-3-14**] without
   complication. Echo [**3-15**] shows mild residual shunt.
   - Repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - Continue aspirin at 81, off plavix due recent GI bleed and
   questionable necessity given no CVA from PFO.
   # Hyponatremia: Likely from volume overload due to heart failure.
   Suspect to improve if able to remove fluid via dialysis.
   - Trend lytes
   - 1000ml fluid restriction
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI IV BID, holding bm regimen given diarrhea
   # ACCESS: PIVs, PICC placement [**2108-3-22**]
   # CODE STATUS: full- confirmed with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   # EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is HCP: [**Name (NI) 831**] ([**0-0-**])
   # DISPOSITION: CCU for CVVH

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure. She was admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. The patient's medical history includes a percutaneous closure of a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with mild residual shunt, ulcerative colitis (UC), and atrial fibrillation (AF). She has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, and acute decompensated diastolic failure.

The patient's current condition includes ongoing GI bleeding, hypotension, anasarca, peripheral edema, and an elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) greater than 15 cm. Her laboratory results show acute kidney injury (AKI) with an increase in serum creatinine, electrolyte imbalances, and anemia. She is also experiencing hyponatremia, which is likely due to volume overload secondary to heart failure.

The patient is currently receiving various treatments, including vasopressin for hypotension, ultrafiltration for fluid removal, diuretics for volume overload, and medications for her comorbidities such as AF and UC. She is also receiving prophylactic treatments for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers.

   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers,
   hct stable at 24 for over 24hrs, with baseline hct mid-upper 20s. Had
   multiple episodes of clots from rectum (Q15mins) overnight. Called GI
   and did NGL which was negative making UGIB less likely.  Transfused one
   unit pRBCs. Awaiting follow up Hct.
   - Hct Q2H
   - GI to consult formally today. [**Month (only) 60**] need to rescope
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: Still resistant to diureisis.
   Suspect not diuresing due to poor forward flow from right heart failure
   (left heart seeing low filling volumes). With gross fluid overload
   dilated right ventricle is likely worsening diastolic dysfunction and
   removing the excess fluid is likely the only way the patient will
   improve clinically. As she did not improve over day today with lasix
   gtt at 30/hr she has been transferred to CCU for ultrafiltration to
   help with fluid removal.
   - On UF with net negative 500mL. Goal is net negative 4L today.
   - Will need A-line for better BP measurements as cuff not [**Location (un) 308**] well
   - Renal will continue to follow and leave recs for CVVH
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction
   - Will continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Will continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence
   this does improve diastolic CHF.
   # Diarrhea: Likely from blood in GI tract still. Also consider C diff
   given prolonged hospitalization. No fevers, no evidence of infectious
   colitis on scope.
   - C Diff pending
   - Loperamide PRN if C diff negative
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr continued to trend up over
   the course of today. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely secondary to
   poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not suggestive
   of ATN. Concern that she will develop ischemic ATN if renal perfusion
   does not improve.
   - Appreciate renal recs
   - UF as above
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient has chronic persistent AF.
   - Control rate with beta blocker to allow as much diastolic filling of
   hypertrophied LV as possible.
   - Continue ASA for ppx->no coumadin given GIB recently

   - Repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - Continue aspirin at 81, off plavix due recent GI bleed and
   questionable necessity given no CVA from PFO.
   # Hyponatremia: Likely from volume overload due to heart failure.
   Suspect to improve if able to remove fluid via dialysis.
   - Trend lytes

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with a history of severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure. She was admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. She has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, and gastrointestinal bleeding (GI bleed). The patient underwent percutaneous closure of a patent foramen ovale (PFO) and has mild residual shunt on echo. She also has chronic persistent atrial fibrillation and is being treated with beta blockers.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. GI bleed: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis and has experienced multiple episodes of frank bloody clots from the rectum. She is at risk for further GI bleeding, and her Hct levels are being monitored closely. She has received a unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and is on ferrous sulfate. A follow-up scope may be necessary.

2. Acute decompensated diastolic failure: The patient is resistant to diuretic therapy and has gross fluid overload, leading to dilated right ventricle and worsening diastolic dysfunction. She is undergoing ultrafiltration in the CCU to remove excess fluid. The goal is to remove a net negative 4 liters of fluid today.

3. ARF (Acute Renal Failure): The patient's creatinine levels are trending up, suggesting worsening renal function.

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers,
   hct stable at 24 for over 24hrs, with baseline hct mid-upper 20s. Had
   multiple episodes of clots from rectum (Q15mins) overnight. Called GI
   and did NGL which was negative making UGIB less likely.  Transfused one
   unit pRBCs. Awaiting follow up Hct.
   - Hct Q2H
   - GI to consult formally today. [**Month (only) 60**] need to rescope
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: Still resistant to diureisis.
   Suspect not diuresing due to poor forward flow from right heart failure
   (left heart seeing low filling volumes). With gross fluid overload
   dilated right ventricle is likely worsening diastolic dysfunction and
   removing the excess fluid is likely the only way the patient will
   improve clinically. As she did not improve over day today with lasix
   gtt at 30/hr she has been transferred to CCU for ultrafiltration to
   help with fluid removal.
   - On UF with net negative 500mL. Goal is net negative 4L today.
   - Will need A-line for better BP measurements as cuff not [**Location (un) 308**] well
   - Renal will continue to follow and leave recs for CVVH
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction
   - Will continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Will continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence
   this does improve diastolic CHF.
   # Diarrhea: Likely from blood in GI tract still. Also consider C diff
   given prolonged hospitalization. No fevers, no evidence of infectious
   colitis on scope.
   - C Diff pending
   - Loperamide PRN if C diff negative
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr continued to trend up over
   the course of today. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely secondary to
   poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not suggestive
   of ATN. Concern that she will develop ischemic ATN if renal perfusion
   does not improve.
   - Appreciate renal recs
   - UF as above
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient has chronic persistent AF.
   - Control rate with beta blocker to allow as much diastolic filling of
   hypertrophied LV as possible.
   - Continue ASA for ppx->no coumadin given GIB recently
   # s/p PFO closure: s/p percutaneous closure [**2108-3-14**] without
   complication. Echo [**3-15**] shows mild residual shunt.
   - Repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - Continue aspirin at 81, off plavix due recent GI bleed and
   questionable necessity given no CVA from PFO.
   # Hyponatremia: Likely from volume overload due to heart failure.
   Suspect to improve if able to remove fluid via dialysis.
   - Trend lytes
   - 1000ml fluid restriction
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI IV BID, holding bm regimen given diarrhea

2. The patient has been placed on dialysis catheter and started ultrafiltration (UF) due to fluid overload and resistant diuresis.

4. The patient's hemoglobin (Hct) levels have been dropping, indicating ongoing blood loss or inadequate production.
5. The patient's renal function is deteriorating, with increasing serum creatinine levels and oliguria (low urine output).
6. The patient has atrial fibrillation (AF) with rapid ventricular response, and rate control measures are in place.
7. The patient underwent percutaneous closure of a patent foramen ovale (PFO) without complication, but there is a mild residual shunt seen on echocardiogram.

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers,
   hct stable at 24 for over 24hrs, with baseline hct mid-upper 20s. Had
   multiple episodes of clots from rectum (Q15mins) overnight. Called GI
   and did NGL which was negative making UGIB less likely.  Transfused one
   unit pRBCs. Awaiting follow up Hct.
   - Hct Q2H
   - GI to consult formally today. [**Month (only) 60**] need to rescope
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: Still resistant to diureisis.
   Suspect not diuresing due to poor forward flow from right heart failure
   (left heart seeing low filling volumes). With gross fluid overload
   dilated right ventricle is likely worsening diastolic dysfunction and
   removing the excess fluid is likely the only way the patient will
   improve clinically. As she did not improve over day today with lasix
   gtt at 30/hr she has been transferred to CCU for ultrafiltration to
   help with fluid removal.
   - On UF with net negative 500mL. Goal is net negative 4L today.
   - Will need A-line for better BP measurements as cuff not [**Location (un) 308**] well
   - Renal will continue to follow and leave recs for CVVH
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction
   - Will continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Will continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence
   this does improve diastolic CHF.
   # Diarrhea: Likely from blood in GI tract still. Also consider C diff
   given prolonged hospitalization. No fevers, no evidence of infectious
   colitis on scope.
   - C Diff pending
   - Loperamide PRN if C diff negative
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr continued to trend up over
   the course of today. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely secondary to
   poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not suggestive
   of ATN. Concern that she will develop ischemic ATN if renal perfusion
   does not improve.
   - Appreciate renal recs
   - UF as above
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient has chronic persistent AF.
   - Control rate with beta blocker to allow as much diastolic filling of
   hypertrophied LV as possible.
   - Continue ASA for ppx->no coumadin given GIB recently
   # s/p PFO closure: s/p percutaneous closure [**2108-3-14**] without
   complication. Echo [**3-15**] shows mild residual shunt.
   - Repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - Continue aspirin at 81, off plavix due recent GI bleed and
   questionable necessity given no CVA from PFO.
   # Hyponatremia: Likely from volume overload due to heart failure.
   Suspect to improve if able to remove fluid via dialysis.
   - Trend lytes
   - 1000ml fluid restriction
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI IV BID, holding bm regimen given diarrhea
   # ACCESS: PIVs, PICC placement [**2108-3-22**]
   # CODE STATUS: full- confirmed with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   # EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is HCP: [**Name (NI) 831**] ([**0-0-**])

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF. GI on board, rec monitoring
   HCT and if this decreases they may go in again to evaluate, however
   unlikely.
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures (thus making the
   concern for idiopathic pulm HTN unlikely). Ovenight there was a problem
   with UF machine and did not get fluid out. Continued on Vasopressing
   with MAP of 64 (average).
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction.  Will add phenylephrine today.
   - Continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   - Will check CI today and trend.
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr continued to trend up over
   the course of today. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely secondary to
   poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not suggestive
   of ATN. Concern that she will develop ischemic ATN if renal perfusion
   does not improve.
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renal is following
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient has chronic persistent AF.
   - Control rate with beta blocker to allow as much diastolic filling of
   hypertrophied LV as possible.
   - Continue ASA for ppx->no coumadin given GIB recently
   # s/p PFO closure: s/p percutaneous closure [**2108-3-14**] without
   complication. Echo [**3-15**] shows mild residual shunt.
   - Repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - Continue aspirin at 81, off plavix due recent GI bleed and
   questionable necessity given no CVA from PFO.
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI IV BID, holding bm regimen given diarrhea
   # ACCESS: PIVs, PICC placement [**2108-3-22**]
   # CODE STATUS: full- confirmed with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   # EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is HCP: [**Name (NI) 831**] ([**0-0-**])
   # DISPOSITION: CCU for CVVH

   ------ Protected Section ------
   Right heart cath showed perfectly normal PVR under all conditions; as
   well as moderate pulmonary htn.  The entirety of her syndrome is
   therefore explained by chronic severe elevation of left atrial
   pressure, and NOT intrinsic pulmonarty parenchymal or vascular
   disease.  In the absence of mitral regurgitation, mitral stenosis, and
   left ventricular contractile dysfunction (all of which she does not
   have), then the only explanation is severe diastolic dysfunction of the
   left ventricle, as I originally hypothesized.  She clearly does not
   have primary pulmonary hypertension, as her PVR is perfectly normal.
   For now we must continue to pursue aggressive volume unloading through
   hemofiltration.  Also need to keep heart rate in the lowish range with
   in Lopressor.  Will continue ranolazine for its possible lusitropic
   effect.
   Her severe tricuspid regurgitation is due to chronic right heart
   pressure and volume overload, which in turn is secondary to her extreme
   LV diastolic dysfunction, and not to any obvious abnormality of the
   valve itself.  Therefore, as I see it at this time, there can be no
   benefit to be derived from repair or replacement of the tricuspid
   valve, because to do so does not address the underlying cause of her TR
   or right heart failure, and could result in worsening of RV function
   (although it could be argued that worse RV function is acceptable if
   the forward RV stroke volume is increased and the regurgitant fraction
   is markedly reduced.

She has been admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension, with a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) and has undergone clipping/injection of ulcers. She is currently experiencing active LGIB (lower gastrointestinal bleed), which is believed to be precipitated by CHF. The patient is being monitored closely for any changes in hemoglobin concentration (HCT) and may undergo further evaluation if there is a significant decrease.

The patient's cardiac status is a major concern. She has acute decompensated diastolic failure, as evidenced by elevated right ventricular (RV) and left ventricular (LV) pressures on the right heart catheterization. However, there are no elevated pulmonary pressures, making idiopathic pulmonary hypertension unlikely. The patient is receiving vasopressin for hypotension, with a target mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 64. She is also on beta-blockers for heart rate control and to prevent worsening of diastolic dysfunction. Ranolazine is being continued for its potential beneficial effects on diastolic CHF.

The patient also has chronic renal failure, with creatinine levels trending upwards. This is likely secondary to poor forward flow from heart

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic HF admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. She has a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) and underwent percutaneous closure of patent foramen ovale (PFO). The patient has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, GI bleeding, and unsuccessful ultrafiltration due to a malfunctioning machine. She continues to have ongoing LGIB and requires ongoing monitoring of HCT.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Acute decompensated diastolic failure: The patient's diastolic dysfunction may worsen due to tachycardia, leading to further compromise in cardiac output.
2. ARF (acute renal failure): The patient's renal function continues to deteriorate, and there is a concern for ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) if renal perfusion does not improve.
3. GI bleeding: Although the patient's current GI bleeding appears stable, there is a risk of re-bleeding or progression of the current bleed.
4. Volume overload: The patient's ongoing volume overload increases the risk of further cardiac complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension requires ongoing management with vasopressors to maintain adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP).

Please note that this is a summary of the patient's medical history

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF. GI on board, rec monitoring
   HCT and if this decreases they may go in again to evaluate, however
   unlikely.
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures (thus making the
   concern for idiopathic pulm HTN unlikely). Ovenight there was a problem
   with UF machine and did not get fluid out. Continued on Vasopressing
   with MAP of 64 (average).
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction.  Will add phenylephrine today.
   - Continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   - Will check CI today and trend.
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr continued to trend up over
   the course of today. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely secondary to
   poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not suggestive
   of ATN. Concern that she will develop ischemic ATN if renal perfusion
   does not improve.
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renal is following
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient has chronic persistent AF.
   - Control rate with beta blocker to allow as much diastolic filling of
   hypertrophied LV as possible.
   - Continue ASA for ppx->no coumadin given GIB recently
   # s/p PFO closure: s/p percutaneous closure [**2108-3-14**] without
   complication. Echo [**3-15**] shows mild residual shunt.
   - Repeat echo in 8 weeks
   - Continue aspirin at 81, off plavix due recent GI bleed and
   questionable necessity given no CVA from PFO.
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI IV BID, holding bm regimen given diarrhea
   # ACCESS: PIVs, PICC placement [**2108-3-22**]

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. She has a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding (GI bleed), and a percutaneous puncture occlusion (PFO) repair with an endovascular device. She was transferred from the cardiology floor to the critical care unit (CCU) for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen with very active LGIB overnight.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Decompensated Diastolic Failure: The patient's diastolic dysfunction is worsening, as evidenced by elevated right ventricular (RV) and left ventricular (LV) pressures. This can lead to further pulmonary edema and respiratory distress.
2. Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, indicating worsening renal function. This may progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed appropriately.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding (GI Bleed): The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis and has experienced GI bleeding. There is a risk of re-bleeding or ongoing bleeding, which could necessitate additional interventions.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has chronic persistent atrial fibrillation, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, stroke, and

- The patient has ARF, stage III chronic renal failure with increasing Cr levels.
- She is undergoing UF with aggressive diuresis and avoidance of nephrotoxins.
- The patient has chronic persistent AF and is being treated with a beta blocker to control rate.
- She had percutaneous closure of PFO without complication, but there is a mild residual shunt on echo.
- The patient is on PPI

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   #. Leukocytosis: Concerned for occult sepsis given prolonged hospital
   course and hypotension.
   -          Will check U/A, Bcx, Ucx, cxr, and C.Diff
   -          Will treat with abx if necessary
   -          Continue to trend white count
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures (thus making the
   concern for idiopathic pulm HTN unlikely). Continued on Vasopressin
   with MAP of 64 (average).
   - goal fluid balance negative 3-4Liters today with UF
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction.
   - Continue Phenylephrine. Will uptitrate as necessary so that can
   continue aggressive diuresis
   - Continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   - Will check CI today and trend.
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr now trending down possibly
   as result of better forward flow. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely
   secondary to poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not
   suggestive of ATN
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renal is following
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF. GI on board, rec monitoring
   HCT and if this decreases they may go in again to evaluate, however
   unlikely now that venous pressures are decreased.
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22

   ------ Protected Section ------
   Ultrafiltration is going well.  She has an elevated wbc and low
   systemic vascular resistance although no obvious infectious focus.  We
   will check cxr, bld and urine cultures.  No abx for now.
   I remain puzzled by her hemodynamics.  If her cardiac index is normal
   or supranormal, then why should she require ultrafiltration for volume
   regulation in the presence of presumably intact kidneys?
   For now, we will continue ranolazine for diastolic function, beta
   blocker to moderate heart rate, ultrafiltration (aggressive) to volume
   unload, ppi for ulcers.  Prognosis is uncertain at this time.  I am
   hoping that by aggressively volume unloading, her right heart will
   shrink down, the tricuspid regurgitation decrease, and her tendency for
   fluid avidity be reduced.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 3179**]  on:[**2108-3-25**]
   12:55 ------

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure. She was admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. Her hospital course has been complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, GI bleeding, and a percutaneous pulmonary valve (PFO) repair. She was transferred from the cardiology floor to the critical care unit (CCU) for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen. 

The patient's current condition includes acute decompensated diastolic failure, chronic renal failure, GI bleeding, and leukocytosis. She is being treated with vasopressin, phenylephrine, beta-blockers, ranolazine, fluid restriction, and continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) for fluid overload and renal failure. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Occult sepsis: The patient has leukocytosis, which raises concern for occult sepsis, especially considering her prolonged hospital course and hypotension. Further investigations, such as urine analysis, blood cultures, and a chest X-ray, will be done to evaluate for infection. Antibiotics may be initiated if necessary.
2. Acute decompensated diastolic failure: The patient has elevated right and left ventricular pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures. She will continue on vasopressin with aggressive fluid removal

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure. She was admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. Her hospital course has been complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and the repair of a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with an endovascular device.

The patient is currently in the cardiac care unit (CCU) for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen. She has an active lower gastrointestinal bleed (LGIB) and is being monitored closely with regular checks on hemoglobin concentration. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and there are concerns for occult sepsis. The patient's acute decompensated diastolic failure is being managed with vasopressin to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 64, aggressive fluid removal through ultrafiltration, and continued diuretic therapy.    62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   #. Leukocytosis: Concerned for occult sepsis given prolonged hospital
   course and hypotension. PA line cx GNR
. Will start on cefepime/levo
   and tailor based on speciation after discussing with ID to get
   approval. Consider aztreonam if supply available.
   - Continue to trend white count
   - d/c pa catheter
   #. UTI: Complicated. CiproX14 days. Last dose [**2108-4-9**].
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures (thus making the
   concern for idiopathic pulm HTN unlikely). Continued on Vasopressin
   with MAP of 64 (average).
   - negative 3-4Liters today with UF
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction.
   - Continue Phenylephrine. Will uptitrate as necessary so that can
   continue aggressive diuresis
   - Continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr now trending down possibly
   as result of better forward flow. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely
   secondary to poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not
   suggestive of ATN
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renal is following
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF. GI on board, rec monitoring
   HCT and if this decreases they may go in again to evaluate, however
   unlikely now that venous pressures are decreased.
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S , Transfuse for hct < 22

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. She has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and a percutaneous pulmonary valve replacement.

The patient's current medical complications include leukocytosis with a possible occult sepsis, complicated urinary tract infection (UTI), acute decompensated diastolic failure, chronic renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and peripheral arterial disease.

The patient is currently being treated with various medications such as vasopressin, phenylephrine, metoprolol, ranolazine, heparin sodium, pantoprazole, and ferrous sulfate. She is also undergoing ultrafiltration for volume overload and has a percutaneous pulmonary valve replacement.

Further assessments and plans include treating the leukocytosis with antibiotics, discontinuing the PA catheter, continuing aggressive diuresis for diastolic failure, tailoring the antibiotic regimen based on culture results, and monitoring the patient's response to treatment.

The patient is a 62-year-old woman admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. She has a history of severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure. The patient's hospital course has been complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and a percutaneous pulmonary valve replacement (PFO) repair with an endovascular device.

The patient's current condition includes acute decompensated diastolic failure, acute kidney injury (ARF) stage III chronic renal failure, and gastrointestinal bleeding. She is currently in the critical care unit (CCU) for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

The patient's laboratory results show:

- Phosphorus: 2.2 mg/dL

- HEENT: Normocephalic (head size within normal range), atraumatic (no evidence of trauma), no scleral icterus (yellowing of the white part of the eyes), MMM (mouth, mouth mucosa)
- CARDIAC: Irregularly irregular (irregular heartbeat), no murmurs (abnormal heart sounds), JVP (jugular venous pressure) >15cm
- LUNGS: Crackles in left lower lobe (LLL), rest clear to auscultation (listening to lung sounds)
- ABDOMEN: NABS (no abnormal bowel sounds), distended mild right lower quadrant (RLQ), tenderness without rebound or guarding
- EXTREMITIES: 4+ lower extremity peripheral edema (swelling in the legs), 2+ left upper extremity (LUE) edema, 2+ right upper extremity (RUE) edema, 2+ radial pulses with 3-second capillary refill, lower extremities warm
- NEURO: Alert and oriented to time, place, and person, appropriate
- PSYCH: Listens and responds appropriately, pleasant

The patient's medical and family history includes severe diastolic CHF, right-sided systolic HF, hypoxia, diarrhea, hypotension, PFO repair with endovascular device, and long hospital course.

The patient's potential medical complications include leukocytosis, acute decompensated diastolic failure, ARF stage III chronic renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and volume overload. The patient's current treatment plan includes ultrafiltration, vasopressin for hypotension, aggressive diuretic regimen, and renal dosing of medications.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman admitted to the ICU for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. She has a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, GI bleeding, and a previous PFO repair with endovascular device placement. The patient has severe diastolic congestive heart failure and right-sided systolic heart failure. She underwent an endovascular device placement for PFO repair and was transferred to the CCU for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Bacteremia: The patient has bacteremia with growth of GNR from the PA line and GPC from the a-line. She was treated with Vanc/Aztreonam/Cipro (day 2) and the lines were removed. Blood cultures will be followed up for bacteremia, C. difficile, and sensitivities.
2. UTI: The patient has a urinary tract infection with GNRs in the urine culture. She is being treated with Cipro/Aztreonam.
3. Acute decompensated diastolic failure: The patient has severe diastolic failure with elevated right and left ventricular pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) shows severe tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and right heart failure (RHF). Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is within normal limits. The patient requires aggressive fluid removal due to severe volume overload.
4. ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF) with an increasing creatinine level. It is likely secondary to poor forward flow from heart failure. Aggressive diuresis and ultrafiltration are planned.
5. GI bleeding: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis and has had GI bleeding. Most likely precipitant for the bleed is congestive heart failure. The patient will continue to be monitored for further bleeding episodes.
6. PFO repair with endovascular device: The patient underwent a PFO repair with endovascular device placement. She will require close monitoring for any complications related to the device.
7. Fluid overload: The patient has ongoing fluid overload, which needs to be managed aggressively through ultrafiltration and diuretics.
8. Hypotension: The patient is hypotensive and requires vasopressin and phenylephrine infusion for hemodynamic support.
9. Diastolic dysfunction: The patient has diastolic dysfunction and will require beta-blocker therapy for rate control and ranolazine for diastolic function improvement.
10. Chronic renal failure: The patient has stage III chronic renal failure. Renal dosing of medications and avoiding nephrotoxins are necessary. Dialysis may be required if electrolyte imbalances worsen.

Please note that this summary is based on the provided progress

4. Chronic renal failure: The patient has stage III chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level trending down possibly as a result of better forward flow.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure. She was admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. The patient has had a prolonged hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and a previously repaired patent foramen ovale (PFO) with an endovascular device.

Medical Complications:
1. Bacteremia: The patient had bacteremia caused by Gram-negative rods (GNR) from both peripheral arterial (PA) and arterial lines. She received antibiotics (Vanc/Aztreonam/Cipro) and the lines were removed.
2. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The patient had a UTI caused by GNRs in her urinary catheter (UCx). She was treated with antibiotics (Cipro/Aztreonam).
3. Acute Decompensated Diastolic Failure: The patient has acute decompensated diastolic failure with severe tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and right heart failure (RHF). Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is within normal limits. There is no evidence of pulmonary hypertension.
4. Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has stage III chronic renal failure with worsening renal function. She is undergoing continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and ultrafiltration (UF).
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient had a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) and experienced gastrointestinal bleeding. She is currently stable, but requires ongoing management.
6. Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO): The patient had a PFO repair with an endovascular device.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Fluid Overload: The patient continues to have volume overload despite ultrafiltration. The goal is to achieve a negative fluid balance of 4 liters today.
2. Hypotension: The patient remains hypotensive despite vasopressor support with vasopressin and phenylephrine. The target mean arterial pressure (MAP) is 60.
3. Diuretic Therapy: The patient is on an aggressive diuretic regimen.
4. Renal Function: The patient's renal function is being monitored closely, and if there is no urine output, chronic dialysis may be considered.
5. Gastrointestinal Management: The patient requires continued prophylaxis for stress ulcers and consideration for changing to oral proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) when more stable. Ferrous sulfate is provided for iron supplementation.
6. Electrolyte Management: The patient's electrolytes are managed through CVVH.
7. Code Status: The patient has confirmed full code status.

Please note that this summary is based on the provided information and there may be additional details or complexities in the patient's case.

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen with very active
   LGIB overnight.
   #. Leukocytosis: Concerned for occult sepsis given prolonged hospital
   course and hypotension.
   -          Will check U/A, Bcx, Ucx, cxr, and C.Diff
   -          Will treat with abx if necessary
   -          Continue to trend white count
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures (thus making the
   concern for idiopathic pulm HTN unlikely). Continued on Vasopressin
   with MAP of 64 (average).
   - goal fluid balance negative 3-4Liters today with UF
   -Continue vasopressin for hypotension with aggressive fluid removal as
   this will have no B1 activity and will not increase heart rate which
   would worsen her diastolic dysfunction.
   - Continue Phenylephrine. Will uptitrate as necessary so that can
   continue aggressive diuresis
   - Continue beta blocker for HR control given diastolic CHF will be
   worsened from tachycardia and want to give LV long enough time to
   fill.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   - Will check CI today and trend.
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr now trending down possibly
   as result of better forward flow. Lytes suggested pre-renal. Likely
   secondary to poor forward flow from heart failure; urine microscopy not
   suggestive of ATN
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - No need for dialysis now as electrolytes wnl
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renal is following
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF. GI on board, rec monitoring
   HCT and if this decreases they may go in again to evaluate, however
   unlikely now that venous pressures are decreased.
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **], ferrous sulfate
   - PIV x2  plus CVL
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI IV BID, holding bm regimen given diarrhea
   # ACCESS: PIVs, PICC placement [**2108-3-22**]
   # CODE STATUS: full- confirmed with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   # EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is HCP: [**Name (NI) 831**] ([**0-0-**])
   # DISPOSITION: CCU for UF

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure (HF) admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. The patient has had a prolonged hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and a perforated septal occluder device (PFO) repair.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Occult sepsis: The patient's prolonged hospital course and hypotension raise concerns for occult sepsis. Leukocytosis is present, and further investigations such as urine analysis (U/A), blood culture (Bcx), urine culture (Ucx), chest X-ray (CXR), and Clostridium difficile testing will be performed to rule out infection. Antibiotics will be initiated if necessary.

2. Acute decompensated diastolic failure: The patient's diastolic dysfunction is worsening, as evidenced by elevated right and left ventricular pressures on right heart catheterization. Vasopressin will be continued for hypotension, aiming for a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 64. Aggressive fluid removal through ultrafiltration (UF) will be continued to achieve a negative fluid balance of 3-4 liters today. Phenylephrine will be uptitrated to maintain adequate systemic vascular resistance and allow for aggressive diuresis

   [3+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic
   pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the prior TTE study (images reviewed) of [**2108-3-22**], the
   findings are similar.

   could be pneumonia.

   ------ Protected Section ------
   I anticipate the need for 24 to 48 h more ultrafiltration at the
   present rate of volume unloading.  The major question is whether her
   kidneys will work once ultrafiltration is discontinued.  I am beginning
   to suspect that her systemic vasodilatation, presumably secondary to
   sepsis, may be shunting blood flow away from kidneys.  Therefore, I
   would now like to be more aggressive in supporting blood pressure with
   vasopressin (already maxed) and phenylephrine.  We will now maintain
   sbp > 100 mmHg and mean arterial pressure > 60 mmHg.  Otherwise will
   continue aggressive volume unloading, heart rate control, ranolazine.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with a history of severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure (RHF). She was admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. Her hospital course has been complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and a perforated patent foramen ovale (PFO) repair with an endovascular device. She was transferred from the cardiology floor to the critical care unit (CCU) for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen.

Medical Complications:
1. Bacteremia: Blood cultures from the pulmonary artery (PA) line grew Gram-negative rods (GNR), and from the arterial line (A-line) grew Gram-positive cocci (GPC). The patient is on vancomycin, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin.
2. Urinary tract infection (UTI): GNRs were found in the urine culture, and the patient is on ciprofloxacin and aztreonam.
3. Acute decompensated diastolic failure: The patient has elevated right ventricular (RV) and left ventricular (LV) pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows severe tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and right heart failure (RHF).
4. Chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine is trending down with continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH)/ultrafiltration (UF). She is still experiencing low urine output.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) and has had previous episodes of GI bleeding. The most likely precipitant for this bleed is CHF. She is stable, and her current management includes intravenous proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and ferrous sulfate for transfusion.
6. Fluid overload: The patient has been experiencing ongoing fluid overload, and her fluid balance is negative.
7. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing persistent hypotension, and her mean arterial pressure (MAP) is below 60 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: Given the presence of bacteremia and UTI, there is a risk of sepsis.
2. Worsening renal function: The patient's renal function may continue to deteriorate despite CVVH/UF.
3. Further gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of UC and previous episodes of GI bleeding put her at risk for further bleeding events.
4. Right ventricular failure: The severe TR and RHF seen on TTE indicate ongoing right-sided heart dysfunction, which may lead to further decompensation.
5. Infection control: With multiple lines and catheters in place, there is a risk of central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI) or catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI).
6. Cardiogenic shock: The combination of severe TR, RHF, and hypotension may increase the risk of cardiogenic shock.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old woman with a history of severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right systolic heart failure. She was admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. The patient has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, GI bleeding, and a previous procedure for a patent foramen ovale (PFO) repair with an endovascular device.

The patient's current condition includes bacteremia/sepsis caused by Serratia marcescens, which is sensitive to certain antibiotics but resistant to others. She also has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by gram-negative rods, which is being treated with ciprofloxacin and aztreonam. The patient's acute decompensated diastolic failure is being managed with ultrafiltration, vasopressin, and phenylephrine to maintain fluid balance and blood pressure. She also has chronic renal failure, and efforts are being made to improve urine output through aggressive diuretic therapy and consideration of chronic dialysis if needed.

The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is believed to be precipitated by CHF. She is receiving intravenous proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and is being considered for conversion to oral PPI when more stable. The patient's electrolyte levels are being managed through continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and fluid restriction.

   Assessment and Plan
   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course
   complicated by volume overload (ongoing), worsening renal failure
   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,
   transferred from cardiology floor to CCU for Ultrafiltration after
   failing to increase UOP on aggressive diuretic regimen.
   # Bacteremia/sepsis: BCx from pa-line grew Seratia Marcesans S to
   cefalosporins, tobramycin, meropenem, imi. Awaiting sensitivity to
   aztreonam. From a-line grew GPCs. On Vanc/Aztreonam/Cipro (day 3).
   Lines d/c
   - Will f/u Bcx, C.diff and sensitivities on blood cultures/urine
   cultures
   - Continue to trend white count
   - PA, A line out. Keeping dialysis catheter for it therapeutic
   necessity (daily BCx from dialysis line)
   - Foley D/C
   - Consider ID consult for antibiotic regimen given limited supply of
   aztreonam and multiple allergies to other medications to treat GNRs.
   - Cotinue Vanc with dosing per level. Today was 14.7 so can give
   another dose and recheck level prior to next dose.
   # UTI: GNRs in UCx. On Cipro/Aztreonam. Awaiting sensitivities to
   aztreonam but sensitive to cipro
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures (thus making the
   concern for idiopathic pulm HTN unlikely). TTE shows severe TR and RHF.
   LVEF wnl. Net negative over17L for LOS in CCU with exam consistent with
   less volume overload.
   - Unfortunately, requiring more pressors to continue to get fluids off
   so may need to back off UF goal today
   - Decreased BPs may also be from increasing the beta blocker although
   this would have had a very small effect on BP and may actually increase
   her CO/BP by decreasing her HR. Will discuss with attending.
   - Continue vasopressin and Phenylephrine for hypotension. MAP 60.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr now trending down with
   CVVH/UF. Still low U/O.
   - Now that foley out consider bladder scan if UOP continues to be poor.
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - Renal is following
   - Will recheck urine lytes.
   - if no urine output will consider chronic dialysis
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF.
   - Hct slightly down from prior but suspect dilutional since less
   negative today than prior days and hct dropped in proportion.
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **] and consider changing to PO when more stable,
   ferrous sulfate
   - Transfuse for hct < 22
   # FEN: No IVF, electrolytes->per CVVH, N->HH,low salt, fluid
   restriction
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI IV BID, holding bm regimen given diarrhea
   # ACCESS: PIVs, PICC placement [**2108-3-22**]
   # CODE STATUS: full- confirmed with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   # EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is HCP: [**Name (NI) 831**] ([**0-0-**])
   # DISPOSITION: CCU for UF

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. She has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, GI bleeding, and a repaired patent foramen ovale (PFO). She was transferred from the cardiology floor to the critical care unit (CCU) for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen.

The patient's current medical conditions include bacteremia/sepsis, urinary tract infection (UTI), acute decompensated diastolic failure, chronic renal failure, and GI bleeding. She is currently receiving multiple medications for her conditions, including vasopressin, phenylephrine, vancomycin, aztreonam, ciprofloxacin, ranolazine, and others.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia/sepsis is caused by Serratia Marcescens, which is sensitive to certain antibiotics but not to others. It is crucial to monitor her vital signs and adjust antibiotic therapy accordingly.
2. UTI: The patient has a GNR infection in her urine culture. She is currently being treated with ciprofloxacin and aztreonam. Awaiting sensitivity results to aztreonam but sensitive to ciprofloxacin.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension. The patient has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, GI bleeding, PFO repair with an endovascular device, and other medical conditions.

The patient is currently in the CCU for ultrafiltration after failing to increase UOP on an aggressive diuretic regimen. She has been diagnosed with bacteremia/sepsis, UTI, acute decompensated diastolic failure, ARF, stage III chronic renal failure, GI bleeding, and other conditions.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

   62 year old woman with severe diastolic CHF and R systolic HF admitted
   for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension with long hospital course

   (ongoing), GI bleeding (stable), PFO repair with endovascular device,

   # Bacteremia/sepsis: BCx from pa-line grew Seratia Marcesans S to
   cefalosporins, tobramycin, meropenem, imi. Awaiting sensitivity to
   aztreonam. From a-line grew GPCs. On Vanc/Aztreonam/Cipro (day 3).

   - PA, A line out. Keeping dialysis catheter for it therapeutic
   necessity (daily BCx from dialysis line)

   - appreciate ID recs

   # UTI: GNRs in UCx. On Cipro/Aztreonam. Awaiting sensitivities to
   aztreonam but sensitive to cipro. #2 GNR speciation pending.
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures. TTE shows severe
   TR and RHF. LVEF wnl. Net negative over 17L for LOS in CCU with exam
   consistent with less volume overload.
   - Continue vasopressin and Phenylephrine for hypotension. Try to wean
   down pressors with goal MAP 60.
   - Milrinone resulted in tachycardia and decrease in BP, thus it was
   stopped.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr now trending down with
   CVVH/UF. Still low U/O.
   - Now that foley out consider bladder scan if UOP continues to be poor.
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - Renal is following
   - Will recheck urine lytes.
   - if no urine output will consider chronic dialysis
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF.
   - Hct slightly down from prior but suspect dilutional since less
   negative today than prior days and hct dropped in proportion.
   - Continue IV ppi [**Hospital1 **] and consider changing to PO when more stable,

   aztreonam and multiple allergies to other medications to treat GNRs.
   - Cotinue Vanc with dosing per level. Today was 14.7 so can give
   another dose and recheck level prior to next dose.
   # UTI: GNRs in UCx. On Cipro/Aztreonam. Awaiting sensitivities to
   aztreonam but sensitive to cipro
   # Acute decompensated diastolic failure: s/p RH cath showing elevated
   RV, LV pressures but no elevated pulmonary pressures (thus making the
   concern for idiopathic pulm HTN unlikely). TTE shows severe TR and RHF.
   LVEF wnl. Net negative over17L for LOS in CCU with exam consistent with
   less volume overload.
   - Unfortunately, requiring more pressors to continue to get fluids off
   so may need to back off UF goal today
   - Continue vasopressin and Phenylephrine for hypotension. Try to wean
   down pressors with goal MAP 60.
   - Continue Ranolazine for diastolic dysfunction as some evidence this
   does improve diastolic CHF.
   - Continue fluid restriction
   - Add milrinone for better relaxation. Keep BPs up with pressors.
   # ARF, stage III chronic renal failure: Cr now trending down with
   CVVH/UF. Still low U/O.
   - Now that foley out consider bladder scan if UOP continues to be poor.
   - UF as above, with aggressive diuresis
   - Renal is following
   - Will recheck urine lytes.
   - if no urine output will consider chronic dialysis
   # GI BLEEDING: History of UC. Status post clipping/injection of ulcers.
   Most likely precipitant for bleed is CHF.
   - Hct slightly down from prior but suspect dilutional since less
   negative today than prior days and hct dropped in proportion.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and right-sided systolic heart failure (HFrEF) admitted for hypoxia, diarrhea, and hypotension.
- She has had a long hospital course complicated by volume overload, worsening renal failure, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, and a percutaneous femoral occluder (PFO) repair with endovascular device.
- The patient was transferred from the cardiology floor to the critical care unit (CCU) for ultrafiltration after failing to increase urine output on an aggressive diuretic regimen.
- She has bacteremia/sepsis caused by Serratia marcescens, which is sensitive to aztreonam but resistant to cefalosporins, tobramycin, meropenem, and imipenem.
- The patient also has a urinary tract infection (UTI) with Gram-negative rods (GNRs) in the urine cultures.
- She has acute decompensated diastolic failure with severe tricuspid regurgitation and right heart failure (RHF).
- The patient has stage III chronic renal failure with a declining creatinine level due to continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) and ultrafiltration.
- She has a history of GI bleeding caused by ulcerative colitis (UC) and is being treated with intravenous proton pump inhibitors (PPIs
